dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Hence! home, you idle creatures, get you home. Is this a holiday? What, know you not, Being mechanical, you ought not walk Upon a labouring day without the sign Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?

dialogues.speaker: Carpenter
dialogues.line: Why, sir, a carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Marullus
dialogues.line: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule? What dost thou with thy best apparel on? You, sir, what trade are you?

dialogues.speaker: Cobbler
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.

dialogues.speaker: Marullus
dialogues.line: But what trade art thou? Answer me directly.

dialogues.speaker: Cobbler
dialogues.line: A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.

dialogues.speaker: Marullus
dialogues.line: What trade, thou knave? Thou naughty knave, what trade?

dialogues.speaker: Cobbler
dialogues.line: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me; yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you.

dialogues.speaker: Marullus
dialogues.line: What mean'st thou by that? Mend me, thou saucy fellow!

dialogues.speaker: Cobbler
dialogues.line: Why, sir, cobble you.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?

dialogues.speaker: Cobbler
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl; I meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes: when they are in great danger, I recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: But wherefore art not in thy shop today? Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?

dialogues.speaker: Cobbler
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself into more work. But indeed, sir, we make holiday to see Caesar, and to rejoice in his triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Marullus
dialogues.line: Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home? What tributaries follow him to Rome, To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels? You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things! O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome, Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements, To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops, Your infants in your arms, and there have sat The livelong day with patient expectation, To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome. And when you saw his chariot but appear, Have you not made an universal shout, That Tiber trembled underneath her banks To hear the replication of your sounds Made in her concave shores? And do you now put on your best attire? And do you now cull out a holiday? And do you now strew flowers in his way, That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood? Be gone! Run to your houses, fall upon your knees, Pray to the gods to intermit the plague That needs must light on this ingratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault Assemble all the poor men of your sort, Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears Into the channel, till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all. See whether their basest metal be not mov'd; They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness. Go you down that way towards the Capitol; This way will I. Disrobe the images, If you do find them deck'd with ceremonies.

dialogues.speaker: Marullus
dialogues.line: May we do so? You know it is the feast of Lupercal.

dialogues.speaker: Flavius
dialogues.line: It is no matter; let no images Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'll about And drive away the vulgar from the streets; So do you too, where you perceive them thick. These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch, Who else would soar above the view of men, And keep us all in servile fearfulness.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Calphurnia.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Peace, ho! Caesar speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Calphurnia.

dialogues.speaker: Calphurnia
dialogues.line: Here, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Stand you directly in Antonius' way, When he doth run his course. Antonius.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Caesar, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Forget not in your speed, Antonius, To touch Calphurnia; for our elders say, The barren, touched in this holy chase, Shake off their sterile curse.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I shall remember. When Caesar says "Do this," it is perform'd.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Set on; and leave no ceremony out.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Ha! Who calls?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Bid every noise be still; peace yet again!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Who is it in the press that calls on me? I hear a tongue shriller than all the music, Cry "Caesar"! Speak. Caesar is turn'd to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Beware the Ides of March.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What man is that?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: A soothsayer bids you beware the Ides of March.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Set him before me; let me see his face.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Fellow, come from the throng; look upon Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What say'st thou to me now? Speak once again.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Beware the Ides of March.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: He is a dreamer; let us leave him. Pass.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Will you go see the order of the course?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Not I.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I pray you, do.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I am not gamesome: I do lack some part Of that quick spirit that is in Antony. Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires; I'll leave you.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Brutus, I do observe you now of late: I have not from your eyes that gentleness And show of love as I was wont to have. You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand Over your friend that loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Cassius, Be not deceived: if I have veil'd my look, I turn the trouble of my countenance Merely upon myself. Vexed I am Of late with passions of some difference, Conceptions only proper to myself, Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors; But let not therefore my good friends be grieved (Among which number, Cassius, be you one) Nor construe any further my neglect, Than that poor Brutus, with himself at war, Forgets the shows of love to other men.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion; By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations. Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No, Cassius, for the eye sees not itself But by reflection, by some other thing.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: 'Tis just: And it is very much lamented, Brutus, That you have no such mirrors as will turn Your hidden worthiness into your eye, That you might see your shadow. I have heard Where many of the best respect in Rome, (Except immortal Caesar) speaking of Brutus, And groaning underneath this age's yoke, Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius, That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear; And since you know you cannot see yourself So well as by reflection, I, your glass, Will modestly discover to yourself That of yourself which you yet know not of. And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus: Were I a common laugher, or did use To stale with ordinary oaths my love To every new protester; if you know That I do fawn on men, and hug them hard, And after scandal them; or if you know That I profess myself in banqueting, To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What means this shouting? I do fear the people Choose Caesar for their king.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Ay, do you fear it? Then must I think you would not have it so.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I would not, Cassius; yet I love him well, But wherefore do you hold me here so long? What is it that you would impart to me? If it be aught toward the general good, Set honour in one eye and death i' the other, And I will look on both indifferently; For let the gods so speed me as I love The name of honour more than I fear death.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus, As well as I do know your outward favour. Well, honour is the subject of my story. I cannot tell what you and other men Think of this life; but, for my single self, I had as lief not be as live to be In awe of such a thing as I myself. I was born free as Caesar; so were you; We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter's cold as well as he: For once, upon a raw and gusty day, The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores, Caesar said to me, "Dar'st thou, Cassius, now Leap in with me into this angry flood, And swim to yonder point?" Upon the word, Accoutred as I was, I plunged in, And bade him follow: so indeed he did. The torrent roar'd, and we did buffet it With lusty sinews, throwing it aside And stemming it with hearts of controversy. But ere we could arrive the point propos'd, Caesar cried, "Help me, Cassius, or I sink!" I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor, Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber Did I the tired Caesar. And this man Is now become a god; and Cassius is A wretched creature, and must bend his body, If Caesar carelessly but nod on him. He had a fever when he was in Spain, And when the fit was on him I did mark How he did shake: 'tis true, this god did shake: His coward lips did from their colour fly, And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world Did lose his lustre. I did hear him groan: Ay, and that tongue of his, that bade the Romans Mark him, and write his speeches in their books, Alas, it cried, "Give me some drink, Titinius," As a sick girl. Ye gods, it doth amaze me, A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world, And bear the palm alone.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Another general shout? I do believe that these applauses are For some new honours that are heap'd on Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world Like a Colossus, and we petty men Walk under his huge legs, and peep about To find ourselves dishonourable graves. Men at some time are masters of their fates: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, But in ourselves, that we are underlings. "Brutus" and "Caesar": what should be in that "Caesar"? Why should that name be sounded more than yours? Write them together, yours is as fair a name; Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well; Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjure with 'em, "Brutus" will start a spirit as soon as "Caesar." Now in the names of all the gods at once, Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed, That he is grown so great? Age, thou art sham'd! Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods! When went there by an age since the great flood, But it was fam'd with more than with one man? When could they say, till now, that talk'd of Rome, That her wide walls encompass'd but one man? Now is it Rome indeed, and room enough, When there is in it but one only man. O, you and I have heard our fathers say, There was a Brutus once that would have brook'd Th' eternal devil to keep his state in Rome, As easily as a king!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous; What you would work me to, I have some aim: How I have thought of this, and of these times, I shall recount hereafter. For this present, I would not, so with love I might entreat you, Be any further mov'd. What you have said, I will consider; what you have to say I will with patience hear; and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things. Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this: Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome Under these hard conditions as this time Is like to lay upon us.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I am glad that my weak words Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The games are done, and Caesar is returning.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve, And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you What hath proceeded worthy note today.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I will do so. But, look you, Cassius, The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow, And all the rest look like a chidden train: Calphurnia's cheek is pale; and Cicero Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes As we have seen him in the Capitol, Being cross'd in conference by some senators.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Casca will tell us what the matter is.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Antonius.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Caesar?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Let me have men about me that are fat, Sleek-headed men, and such as sleep a-nights: Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look; He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous; He is a noble Roman and well given.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not: Yet if my name were liable to fear, I do not know the man I should avoid So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much, He is a great observer, and he looks Quite through the deeds of men. He loves no plays, As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music. Seldom he smiles; and smiles in such a sort As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit That could be mov'd to smile at anything. Such men as he be never at heart's ease Whiles they behold a greater than themselves, And therefore are they very dangerous. I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar. Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf, And tell me truly what thou think'st of him.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Ay, Casca, tell us what hath chanc'd today, That Caesar looks so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Why, you were with him, were you not?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I should not then ask Casca what had chanc'd.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Why, there was a crown offer'd him; and being offer'd him, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What was the second noise for?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Why, for that too.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Why, for that too.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Was the crown offer'd him thrice?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, was't, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler than other; and at every putting-by mine honest neighbours shouted.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Who offer'd him the crown?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Why, Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: I can as well be hang'd, as tell the manner of it: it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown; yet 'twas not a crown neither, 'twas one of these coronets; and, as I told you, he put it by once: but, for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he offered it to him again: then he put it by again: but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his fingers off it. And then he offered it the third time; he put it the third time by; and still, as he refus'd it, the rabblement hooted, and clapp'd their chopt hands, and threw up their sweaty night-caps, and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because Caesar refus'd the crown, that it had, almost, choked Caesar, for he swooned, and fell down at it. And for mine own part, I durst not laugh, for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: But, soft! I pray you. What, did Caesar swoon?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: He fell down in the market-place, and foam'd at mouth, and was speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: 'Tis very like: he hath the falling-sickness.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: No, Caesar hath it not; but you, and I, And honest Casca, we have the falling-sickness.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: I know not what you mean by that; but I am sure Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and displeased them, as they use to do the players in the theatre, I am no true man.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What said he when he came unto himself?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he pluck'd me ope his doublet, and offer'd them his throat to cut. And I had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so he fell. When he came to himself again, he said, if he had done or said anything amiss, he desir'd their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three or four wenches where I stood cried, "Alas, good soul!" and forgave him with all their hearts. But there's no heed to be taken of them: if Caesar had stabb'd their mothers, they would have done no less.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: And, after that, he came thus sad away?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Did Cicero say anything?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Ay, he spoke Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: To what effect?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Nay, and I tell you that, I'll ne'er look you i' the face again. But those that understood him smil'd at one another and shook their heads; but for mine own part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more news too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs off Caesar's images, are put to silence. Fare you well. There was more foolery yet, if I could remember it.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Will you sup with me tonight, Casca?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: No, I am promis'd forth.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Will you dine with me tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Ay, if I be alive, and your mind hold, and your dinner worth the eating.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Good. I will expect you.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Do so; farewell both.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be! He was quick mettle when he went to school.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: So is he now in execution Of any bold or noble enterprise, However he puts on this tardy form. This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit, Which gives men stomach to digest his words With better appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: And so it is. For this time I will leave you: Tomorrow, if you please to speak with me, I will come home to you; or, if you will, Come home to me, and I will wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I will do so: till then, think of the world. Well, Brutus, thou art noble; yet I see, Thy honourable metal may be wrought From that it is dispos'd: therefore 'tis meet That noble minds keep ever with their likes; For who so firm that cannot be seduc'd? Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutus. If I were Brutus now, and he were Cassius, He should not humour me. I will this night, In several hands, in at his windows throw, As if they came from several citizens, Writings, all tending to the great opinion That Rome holds of his name; wherein obscurely Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at. And after this, let Caesar seat him sure, For we will shake him, or worse days endure.

dialogues.speaker: Cicero
dialogues.line: Good even, Casca: brought you Caesar home? Why are you breathless, and why stare you so?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero, I have seen tempests, when the scolding winds Have riv'd the knotty oaks; and I have seen Th' ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam, To be exalted with the threatening clouds: But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire. Either there is a civil strife in heaven, Or else the world too saucy with the gods, Incenses them to send destruction.

dialogues.speaker: Cicero
dialogues.line: Why, saw you anything more wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: A common slave, you'd know him well by sight, Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand, Not sensible of fire remain'd unscorch'd. Besides, I ha' not since put up my sword, Against the Capitol I met a lion, Who glared upon me, and went surly by, Without annoying me. And there were drawn Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women, Transformed with their fear; who swore they saw Men, all in fire, walk up and down the streets. And yesterday the bird of night did sit, Even at noonday upon the marketplace, Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet, let not men say, "These are their reasons; they are natural"; For I believe, they are portentous things Unto the climate that they point upon.

dialogues.speaker: Cicero
dialogues.line: Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time. But men may construe things after their fashion, Clean from the purpose of the things themselves. Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: He doth, for he did bid Antonius Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Cicero
dialogues.line: Goodnight then, Casca: this disturbed sky Is not to walk in.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Farewell, Cicero.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: A Roman.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Casca, by your voice.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: A very pleasing night to honest men.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Those that have known the earth so full of faults. For my part, I have walk'd about the streets, Submitting me unto the perilous night; And, thus unbraced, Casca, as you see, Have bar'd my bosom to the thunder-stone; And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open The breast of heaven, I did present myself Even in the aim and very flash of it.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: But wherefore did you so much tempt the Heavens? It is the part of men to fear and tremble, When the most mighty gods by tokens send Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: You are dull, Casca; and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman you do want, Or else you use not. You look pale and gaze, And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder, To see the strange impatience of the Heavens: But if you would consider the true cause Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts, Why birds and beasts, from quality and kind; Why old men, fools, and children calculate, Why all these things change from their ordinance, Their natures, and pre-formed faculties, To monstrous quality; why, you shall find That Heaven hath infus'd them with these spirits, To make them instruments of fear and warning Unto some monstrous state. Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man Most like this dreadful night, That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars, As doth the lion in the Capitol; A man no mightier than thyself, or me, In personal action; yet prodigious grown, And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: 'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Let it be who it is: for Romans now Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors; But, woe the while! our fathers' minds are dead, And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits; Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow Mean to establish Caesar as a king; And he shall wear his crown by sea and land, In every place, save here in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I know where I will wear this dagger then; Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius: Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong; Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat. Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass, Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron, Can be retentive to the strength of spirit; But life, being weary of these worldly bars, Never lacks power to dismiss itself. If I know this, know all the world besides, That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: So can I: So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then? Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf, But that he sees the Romans are but sheep: He were no lion, were not Romans hinds. Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws. What trash is Rome, What rubbish, and what offal, when it serves For the base matter to illuminate So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief, Where hast thou led me? I, perhaps, speak this Before a willing bondman: then I know My answer must be made; but I am arm'd, And dangers are to me indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: You speak to Casca, and to such a man That is no fleering tell-tale. Hold, my hand: Be factious for redress of all these griefs, And I will set this foot of mine as far As who goes farthest.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: There's a bargain made. Now know you, Casca, I have mov'd already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honourable-dangerous consequence; And I do know by this, they stay for me In Pompey's Porch: for now, this fearful night, There is no stir or walking in the streets; And the complexion of the element In favour's like the work we have in hand, Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: 'Tis Cinna; I do know him by his gait; He is a friend. Cinna, where haste you so?

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: To find out you. Who's that? Metellus Cimber?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: No, it is Casca, one incorporate To our attempts. Am I not stay'd for, Cinna?

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: I am glad on't. What a fearful night is this! There's two or three of us have seen strange sights.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Am I not stay'd for? tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Yes, you are. O Cassius, if you could But win the noble Brutus to our party-

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Be you content. Good Cinna, take this paper, And look you lay it in the praetor's chair, Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this In at his window; set this up with wax Upon old Brutus' statue: all this done, Repair to Pompey's Porch, where you shall find us. Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: All but Metellus Cimber, and he's gone To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie, And so bestow these papers as you bade me.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: That done, repair to Pompey's theatre. Come, Casca, you and I will yet, ere day, See Brutus at his house: three parts of him Is ours already, and the man entire Upon the next encounter, yields him ours.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: O, he sits high in all the people's hearts! And that which would appear offence in us, His countenance, like richest alchemy, Will change to virtue and to worthiness.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Him, and his worth, and our great need of him, You have right well conceited. Let us go, For it is after midnight; and ere day, We will awake him, and be sure of him.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What, Lucius, ho! I cannot, by the progress of the stars, Give guess how near to day.-Lucius, I say! I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly. When, Lucius, when? Awake, I say! What, Lucius!

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Call'd you, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius: When it is lighted, come and call me here.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I will, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: It must be by his death: and for my part, I know no personal cause to spurn at him, But for the general. He would be crown'd: How that might change his nature, there's the question. It is the bright day that brings forth the adder, And that craves wary walking. Crown him?-that; And then, I grant, we put a sting in him, That at his will he may do danger with. Th' abuse of greatness is, when it disjoins Remorse from power; and, to speak truth of Caesar, I have not known when his affections sway'd More than his reason. But 'tis a common proof, That lowliness is young ambition's ladder, Whereto the climber-upward turns his face; But when he once attains the upmost round, He then unto the ladder turns his back, Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees By which he did ascend. So Caesar may; Then lest he may, prevent. And since the quarrel Will bear no colour for the thing he is, Fashion it thus: that what he is, augmented, Would run to these and these extremities: And therefore think him as a serpent's egg Which hatch'd, would, as his kind grow mischievous; And kill him in the shell.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: The taper burneth in your closet, sir. Searching the window for a flint, I found This paper, thus seal'd up, and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Get you to bed again; it is not day. Is not tomorrow, boy, the Ides of March?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I know not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Look in the calendar, and bring me word.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I will, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The exhalations, whizzing in the air Give so much light that I may read by them. _Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake and see thyself. Shall Rome, &c. Speak, strike, redress!_ "Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake!" Such instigations have been often dropp'd Where I have took them up. "Shall Rome, &c." Thus must I piece it out: Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome? My ancestors did from the streets of Rome The Tarquin drive, when he was call'd a king. "Speak, strike, redress!" Am I entreated To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise, If the redress will follow, thou receivest Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: 'Tis good. Go to the gate, somebody knocks. Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar, I have not slept. Between the acting of a dreadful thing And the first motion, all the interim is Like a phantasma, or a hideous dream: The genius and the mortal instruments Are then in council; and the state of man, Like to a little kingdom, suffers then The nature of an insurrection.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door, Who doth desire to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Is he alone?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: No, sir, there are moe with him.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Do you know them?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: No, sir, their hats are pluck'd about their ears, And half their faces buried in their cloaks, That by no means I may discover them By any mark of favour.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Let 'em enter. They are the faction. O conspiracy, Sham'st thou to show thy dangerous brow by night, When evils are most free? O, then, by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy; Hide it in smiles and affability: For if thou path, thy native semblance on, Not Erebus itself were dim enough To hide thee from prevention.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I think we are too bold upon your rest: Good morrow, Brutus; do we trouble you?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I have been up this hour, awake all night. Know I these men that come along with you?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Yes, every man of them; and no man here But honours you; and everyone doth wish You had but that opinion of yourself Which every noble Roman bears of you. This is Trebonius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He is welcome hither.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: This Decius Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He is welcome too.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: They are all welcome. What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Shall I entreat a word?

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Here lies the east: doth not the day break here?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: O, pardon, sir, it doth; and yon grey lines That fret the clouds are messengers of day.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: You shall confess that you are both deceiv'd. Here, as I point my sword, the Sun arises; Which is a great way growing on the South, Weighing the youthful season of the year. Some two months hence, up higher toward the North He first presents his fire; and the high East Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Give me your hands all over, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: And let us swear our resolution.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No, not an oath. If not the face of men, The sufferance of our souls, the time's abuse- If these be motives weak, break off betimes, And every man hence to his idle bed. So let high-sighted tyranny range on, Till each man drop by lottery. But if these, As I am sure they do, bear fire enough To kindle cowards, and to steel with valour The melting spirits of women; then, countrymen, What need we any spur but our own cause To prick us to redress? what other bond Than secret Romans, that have spoke the word, And will not palter? and what other oath Than honesty to honesty engag'd, That this shall be, or we will fall for it? Swear priests and cowards, and men cautelous, Old feeble carrions, and such suffering souls That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain The even virtue of our enterprise, Nor th' insuppressive mettle of our spirits, To think that or our cause or our performance Did need an oath; when every drop of blood That every Roman bears, and nobly bears, Is guilty of a several bastardy, If he do break the smallest particle Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: But what of Cicero? Shall we sound him? I think he will stand very strong with us.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Let us not leave him out.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: No, by no means.

dialogues.speaker: Metellus
dialogues.line: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion, And buy men's voices to commend our deeds. It shall be said, his judgement rul'd our hands; Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear, But all be buried in his gravity.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O, name him not; let us not break with him; For he will never follow anything That other men begin.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Then leave him out.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Indeed, he is not fit.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Decius, well urg'd. I think it is not meet, Mark Antony, so well belov'd of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar: we shall find of him A shrewd contriver; and you know, his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all; which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off, and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death, and envy afterwards; For Antony is but a limb of Caesar. Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius. We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, And in the spirit of men there is no blood. O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit, And not dismember Caesar! But, alas, Caesar must bleed for it! And, gentle friends, Let's kill him boldly, but not wrathfully; Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods, Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds. And let our hearts, as subtle masters do, Stir up their servants to an act of rage, And after seem to chide 'em. This shall mark Our purpose necessary, and not envious; Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers. And for Mark Antony, think not of him; For he can do no more than Caesar's arm When Caesar's head is off.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Yet I fear him; For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar-

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him: If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself; take thought and die for Caesar. And that were much he should; for he is given To sports, to wildness, and much company.

dialogues.speaker: Trebonius
dialogues.line: There is no fear in him; let him not die; For he will live, and laugh at this hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Peace! count the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: The clock hath stricken three.

dialogues.speaker: Trebonius
dialogues.line: 'Tis time to part.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: But it is doubtful yet Whether Caesar will come forth today or no; For he is superstitious grown of late, Quite from the main opinion he held once Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies. It may be these apparent prodigies, The unaccustom'd terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers, May hold him from the Capitol today.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Never fear that: if he be so resolved, I can o'ersway him, for he loves to hear That unicorns may be betray'd with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers. But when I tell him he hates flatterers, He says he does, being then most flattered. Let me work; For I can give his humour the true bent, And I will bring him to the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Be that the uttermost; and fail not then.

dialogues.speaker: Metellus
dialogues.line: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey; I wonder none of you have thought of him.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Now, good Metellus, go along by him: He loves me well, and I have given him reason; Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: The morning comes upon's. We'll leave you, Brutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves; but all remember What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily; Let not our looks put on our purposes, But bear it as our Roman actors do, With untired spirits and formal constancy. And so, good morrow to you everyone. Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter; Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber: Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies, Which busy care draws in the brains of men; Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Brutus, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Portia, what mean you? Wherefore rise you now? It is not for your health thus to commit Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Nor for yours neither. Y' have ungently, Brutus, Stole from my bed; and yesternight at supper, You suddenly arose, and walk'd about, Musing and sighing, with your arms across; And when I ask'd you what the matter was, You star'd upon me with ungentle looks. I urg'd you further; then you scratch'd your head, And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot; Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not, But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you. So I did, Fearing to strengthen that impatience Which seem'd too much enkindled; and withal Hoping it was but an effect of humour, Which sometime hath his hour with every man. It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep; And could it work so much upon your shape As it hath much prevail'd on your condition, I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord, Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I am not well in health, and that is all.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health, He would embrace the means to come by it.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Is Brutus sick, and is it physical To walk unbraced and suck up the humours Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed To dare the vile contagion of the night, And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus; You have some sick offence within your mind, Which, by the right and virtue of my place, I ought to know of: and, upon my knees, I charm you, by my once commended beauty, By all your vows of love, and that great vow Which did incorporate and make us one, That you unfold to me, your self, your half, Why you are heavy, and what men tonight Have had resort to you; for here have been Some six or seven, who did hide their faces Even from darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Kneel not, gentle Portia.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus. Is it excepted I should know no secrets That appertain to you? Am I your self But, as it were, in sort or limitation, To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed, And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs Of your good pleasure? If it be no more, Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You are my true and honourable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: If this were true, then should I know this secret. I grant I am a woman; but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife; I grant I am a woman; but withal A woman well reputed, Cato's daughter. Think you I am no stronger than my sex, Being so father'd and so husbanded? Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose 'em. I have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here, in the thigh: can I bear that with patience And not my husband's secrets?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O ye gods, Render me worthy of this noble wife! Hark, hark, one knocks. Portia, go in awhile; And by and by thy bosom shall partake The secrets of my heart. All my engagements I will construe to thee, All the charactery of my sad brows. Leave me with haste. Lucius, who's that knocks?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Here is a sick man that would speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of. Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius, how?

dialogues.speaker: Ligarius
dialogues.line: Vouchsafe good-morrow from a feeble tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius, To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!

dialogues.speaker: Ligarius
dialogues.line: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honour.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

dialogues.speaker: Ligarius
dialogues.line: By all the gods that Romans bow before, I here discard my sickness. Soul of Rome! Brave son, derived from honourable loins! Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjur'd up My mortified spirit. Now bid me run, And I will strive with things impossible, Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

dialogues.speaker: Ligarius
dialogues.line: But are not some whole that we must make sick?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: That must we also. What it is, my Caius, I shall unfold to thee, as we are going, To whom it must be done.

dialogues.speaker: Ligarius
dialogues.line: Set on your foot, And with a heart new-fir'd I follow you, To do I know not what; but it sufficeth That Brutus leads me on.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Follow me then.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace tonight: Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out, "Help, ho! They murder Caesar!" Who's within?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice, And bring me their opinions of success.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I will, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Calphurnia
dialogues.line: What mean you, Caesar? Think you to walk forth? You shall not stir out of your house today.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Caesar shall forth. The things that threaten'd me Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see The face of Caesar, they are vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Calphurnia
dialogues.line: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies, Yet now they fright me. There is one within, Besides the things that we have heard and seen, Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch. A lioness hath whelped in the streets, And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead; Fierce fiery warriors fight upon the clouds In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol; The noise of battle hurtled in the air, Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan, And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets. O Caesar, these things are beyond all use, And I do fear them!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What can be avoided Whose end is purpos'd by the mighty gods? Yet Caesar shall go forth; for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Calphurnia
dialogues.line: When beggars die, there are no comets seen; The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Cowards die many times before their deaths; The valiant never taste of death but once. Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come. What say the augurers?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: They would not have you to stir forth today. Plucking the entrails of an offering forth, They could not find a heart within the beast.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The gods do this in shame of cowardice: Caesar should be a beast without a heart If he should stay at home today for fear. No, Caesar shall not. Danger knows full well That Caesar is more dangerous than he. We are two lions litter'd in one day, And I the elder and more terrible, And Caesar shall go forth.

dialogues.speaker: Calphurnia
dialogues.line: Alas, my lord, Your wisdom is consum'd in confidence. Do not go forth today: call it my fear That keeps you in the house, and not your own. We'll send Mark Antony to the Senate-house, And he shall say you are not well today. Let me upon my knee prevail in this.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Mark Antony shall say I am not well, And for thy humour, I will stay at home. Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar. I come to fetch you to the Senate-house.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the Senators, And tell them that I will not come today. Cannot, is false; and that I dare not, falser: I will not come today. Tell them so, Decius.

dialogues.speaker: Calphurnia
dialogues.line: Say he is sick.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell grey-beards the truth? Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The cause is in my will; I will not come. That is enough to satisfy the Senate. But for your private satisfaction, Because I love you, I will let you know: Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home. She dreamt tonight she saw my statue, Which like a fountain with an hundred spouts Did run pure blood; and many lusty Romans Came smiling, and did bathe their hands in it. And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent; and on her knee Hath begg'd that I will stay at home today.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: This dream is all amiss interpreted: It was a vision fair and fortunate. Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bath'd, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance. This by Calphurnia's dream is signified.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: And this way have you well expounded it.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: I have, when you have heard what I can say; And know it now. The Senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar. If you shall send them word you will not come, Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock Apt to be render'd, for someone to say, "Break up the Senate till another time, When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams." If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper "Lo, Caesar is afraid"? Pardon me, Caesar; for my dear dear love To your proceeding bids me tell you this, And reason to my love is liable.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calphurnia! I am ashamed I did yield to them. Give me my robe, for I will go. And look where Publius is come to fetch me.

dialogues.speaker: Publius
dialogues.line: Good morrow, Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Welcome, Publius. What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too? Good morrow, Casca. Caius Ligarius, Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy As that same ague which hath made you lean. What is't o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I thank you for your pains and courtesy. See! Antony, that revels long a-nights, Is notwithstanding up. Good morrow, Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: So to most noble Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Bid them prepare within. I am to blame to be thus waited for. Now, Cinna; now, Metellus; what, Trebonius! I have an hour's talk in store for you: Remember that you call on me today; Be near me, that I may remember you.

dialogues.speaker: Trebonius
dialogues.line: Caesar, I will.  and so near will I be, That your best friends shall wish I had been further.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Good friends, go in, and taste some wine with me; And we, like friends, will straightway go together.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: That every like is not the same, O Caesar, The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon.

dialogues.speaker: Artemidorus
dialogues.line: _"Caesar, beware of Brutus; take heed of Cassius; come not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna; trust not Trebonius; mark well Metellus Cimber; Decius Brutus loves thee not; thou hast wrong'd Caius Ligarius. There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar. If thou be'st not immortal, look about you: security gives way to conspiracy. The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover, Artemidorus."_ Here will I stand till Caesar pass along, And as a suitor will I give him this. My heart laments that virtue cannot live Out of the teeth of emulation. If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayest live; If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.

scenes.location: Another part of the same street, before the house of Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: I pr'ythee, boy, run to the Senate-house; Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone. Why dost thou stay?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: To know my errand, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: I would have had thee there and here again, Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.  O constancy, be strong upon my side, Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue! I have a man's mind, but a woman's might. How hard it is for women to keep counsel! Art thou here yet?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Madam, what should I do? Run to the Capitol, and nothing else? And so return to you, and nothing else?

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth: and take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him. Hark, boy, what noise is that?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I hear none, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Pr'ythee, listen well. I heard a bustling rumour, like a fray, And the wind brings it from the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Come hither, fellow: Which way hast thou been?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: At mine own house, good lady.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: What is't o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: About the ninth hour, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Madam, not yet. I go to take my stand, To see him pass on to the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: That I have, lady, if it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I shall beseech him to befriend himself.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: None that I know will be, much that I fear may chance. Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow. The throng that follows Caesar at the heels, Of Senators, of Praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death: I'll get me to a place more void, and there Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.

dialogues.speaker: Portia
dialogues.line: I must go in.  Ay me, how weak a thing The heart of woman is! O Brutus, The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise! Sure, the boy heard me. Brutus hath a suit That Caesar will not grant. O, I grow faint. Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord; Say I am merry; come to me again, And bring me word what he doth say to thee.

scenes.location: Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The Ides of March are come.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Ay, Caesar; but not gone.

dialogues.speaker: Artemidorus
dialogues.line: Hail, Caesar! Read this schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Trebonius doth desire you to o'er-read, At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

dialogues.speaker: Artemidorus
dialogues.line: O Caesar, read mine first; for mine's a suit That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What touches us ourself shall be last serv'd.

dialogues.speaker: Artemidorus
dialogues.line: Delay not, Caesar. Read it instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What, is the fellow mad?

dialogues.speaker: Publius
dialogues.line: Sirrah, give place.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: What, urge you your petitions in the street? Come to the Capitol. Caesar enters the Capitol, the rest following. All the Senators rise.

dialogues.speaker: Popilius
dialogues.line: I wish your enterprise today may thrive.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: What enterprise, Popilius?

dialogues.speaker: Popilius
dialogues.line: Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What said Popilius Lena?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: He wish'd today our enterprise might thrive. I fear our purpose is discovered.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Look how he makes to Caesar: mark him.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention. Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known, Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back, For I will slay myself.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Cassius, be constant: Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes; For look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Trebonius knows his time, for look you, Brutus, He draws Mark Antony out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go, And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He is address'd; press near and second him.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Are we all ready? What is now amiss That Caesar and his Senate must redress?

dialogues.speaker: Metellus
dialogues.line: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar, Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat An humble heart.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I must prevent thee, Cimber. These couchings and these lowly courtesies Might fire the blood of ordinary men, And turn pre-ordinance and first decree Into the law of children. Be not fond, To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood That will be thaw'd from the true quality With that which melteth fools; I mean sweet words, Low-crooked curtsies, and base spaniel fawning. Thy brother by decree is banished: If thou dost bend, and pray, and fawn for him, I spurn thee like a cur out of my way. Know, Caesar dost not wrong, nor without cause Will he be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Metellus
dialogues.line: Is there no voice more worthy than my own, To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear For the repealing of my banish'd brother?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar; Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What, Brutus?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon: As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall, To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I could be well mov'd, if I were as you; If I could pray to move, prayers would move me: But I am constant as the northern star, Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality There is no fellow in the firmament. The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks, They are all fire, and every one doth shine; But there's but one in all doth hold his place. So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men, And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive; Yet in the number I do know but one That unassailable holds on his rank, Unshak'd of motion: and that I am he, Let me a little show it, even in this, That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd, And constant do remain to keep him so.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: O Caesar,-

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: Great Caesar,-

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Speak, hands, for me!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: _Et tu, Brute?_-Then fall, Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead! Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Some to the common pulpits and cry out, "Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!"

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: People and Senators, be not affrighted. Fly not; stand still; ambition's debt is paid.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: And Cassius too.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Where's Publius?

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

dialogues.speaker: Metellus
dialogues.line: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's Should chance-

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Talk not of standing. Publius, good cheer! There is no harm intended to your person, Nor to no Roman else. So tell them, Publius.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: And leave us, Publius; lest that the people Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Do so; and let no man abide this deed But we the doers.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Where's Antony?

dialogues.speaker: Trebonius
dialogues.line: Fled to his house amaz'd. Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run, As it were doomsday.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Fates, we will know your pleasures. That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

dialogues.speaker: Casca
dialogues.line: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Grant that, and then is death a benefit: So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridg'd His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop, And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords: Then walk we forth, even to the market-place, And waving our red weapons o'er our heads, Let's all cry, "Peace, freedom, and liberty!"

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Stoop then, and wash. How many ages hence Shall this our lofty scene be acted over In States unborn, and accents yet unknown!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport, That now on Pompey's basis lies along, No worthier than the dust!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: So oft as that shall be, So often shall the knot of us be call'd The men that gave their country liberty.

dialogues.speaker: Decius
dialogues.line: What, shall we forth?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Ay, every man away. Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Soft, who comes here? A friend of Antony's.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel; Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down; And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say: Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest; Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving; Say I love Brutus and I honour him; Say I fear'd Caesar, honour'd him, and lov'd him. If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony May safely come to him, and be resolv'd How Caesar hath deserv'd to lie in death, Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead So well as Brutus living; but will follow The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus Thorough the hazards of this untrod state, With all true faith. So says my master Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman; I never thought him worse. Tell him, so please him come unto this place, He shall be satisfied and, by my honour, Depart untouch'd.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I'll fetch him presently.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I wish we may: but yet have I a mind That fears him much; and my misgiving still Falls shrewdly to the purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: But here comes Antony. Welcome, Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: O mighty Caesar! Dost thou lie so low? Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well. I know not, gentlemen, what you intend, Who else must be let blood, who else is rank: If I myself, there is no hour so fit As Caesar's death's hour; nor no instrument Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich With the most noble blood of all this world. I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard, Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke, Fulfill your pleasure. Live a thousand years, I shall not find myself so apt to die. No place will please me so, no means of death, As here by Caesar, and by you cut off, The choice and master spirits of this age.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O Antony, beg not your death of us. Though now we must appear bloody and cruel, As by our hands and this our present act You see we do; yet see you but our hands And this the bleeding business they have done. Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful; And pity to the general wrong of Rome- As fire drives out fire, so pity pity- Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part, To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony; Our arms in strength of malice, and our hearts Of brothers' temper, do receive you in With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's In the disposing of new dignities.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Only be patient till we have appeas'd The multitude, beside themselves with fear, And then we will deliver you the cause Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him, Have thus proceeded.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I doubt not of your wisdom. Let each man render me his bloody hand. First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you; Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand. Now, Decius Brutus, yours; now yours, Metellus; Yours, Cinna; and, my valiant Casca, yours; Though last, not least in love, yours, good Trebonius. Gentlemen all-alas, what shall I say? My credit now stands on such slippery ground, That one of two bad ways you must conceit me, Either a coward or a flatterer. That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true: If then thy spirit look upon us now, Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death, To see thy Antony making his peace, Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes, Most noble, in the presence of thy corse? Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds, Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood, It would become me better than to close In terms of friendship with thine enemies. Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart; Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand, Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy lethe. O world, thou wast the forest to this hart; And this indeed, O world, the heart of thee. How like a deer strucken by many princes, Dost thou here lie!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Mark Antony,-

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Pardon me, Caius Cassius: The enemies of Caesar shall say this; Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I blame you not for praising Caesar so; But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be prick'd in number of our friends, Or shall we on, and not depend on you?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Therefore I took your hands; but was indeed Sway'd from the point, by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all, and love you all, Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons Why, and wherein, Caesar was dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Or else were this a savage spectacle. Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: That's all I seek, And am moreover suitor that I may Produce his body to the market-place; And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend, Speak in the order of his funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You shall, Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Brutus, a word with you.  You know not what you do. Do not consent That Antony speak in his funeral. Know you how much the people may be mov'd By that which he will utter?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: By your pardon: I will myself into the pulpit first, And show the reason of our Caesar's death. What Antony shall speak, I will protest He speaks by leave and by permission; And that we are contented Caesar shall Have all true rights and lawful ceremonies. It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I know not what may fall; I like it not.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body. You shall not in your funeral speech blame us, But speak all good you can devise of Caesar, And say you do't by our permission; Else shall you not have any hand at all About his funeral. And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going, After my speech is ended.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Be it so; I do desire no more.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Prepare the body, then, and follow us.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth, That I am meek and gentle with these butchers. Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever lived in the tide of times. Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood! Over thy wounds now do I prophesy, Which, like dumb mouths do ope their ruby lips To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue, A curse shall light upon the limbs of men; Domestic fury and fierce civil strife Shall cumber all the parts of Italy; Blood and destruction shall be so in use, And dreadful objects so familiar, That mothers shall but smile when they behold Their infants quartered with the hands of war; All pity chok'd with custom of fell deeds: And Caesar's spirit, ranging for revenge, With Ate by his side come hot from Hell, Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice Cry havoc and let slip the dogs of war, That this foul deed shall smell above the earth With carrion men, groaning for burial. You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I do, Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: He did receive his letters, and is coming, And bid me say to you by word of mouth,-  O Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thy heart is big, get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching; for mine eyes, Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine, Began to water. Is thy master coming?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanc'd. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome, No Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence, and tell him so. Yet stay awhile; Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse Into the market-place: there shall I try, In my oration, how the people take The cruel issue of these bloody men; According to the which thou shalt discourse To young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: We will be satisfied; let us be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Then follow me, and give me audience, friends. Cassius, go you into the other street And part the numbers. Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here; Those that will follow Cassius, go with him; And public reasons shall be rendered Of Caesar's death.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: I will hear Brutus speak.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: I will hear Cassius; and compare their reasons, When severally we hear them rendered.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: The noble Brutus is ascended: silence!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Be patient till the last. Romans, countrymen, and lovers, hear me for my cause; and be silent, that you may hear. Believe me for mine honour, and have respect to mine honour, that you may believe. Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses, that you may the better judge. If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar's, to him I say that Brutus' love to Caesar was no less than his. If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living, and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him; as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was valiant, I honour him; but, as he was ambitious, I slew him. There is tears, for his love; joy for his fortune; honour for his valour; and death, for his ambition. Who is here so base, that would be a bondman? If any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so rude, that would not be a Roman? If any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so vile, that will not love his country? If any, speak; for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: None, Brutus, none.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Then none have I offended. I have done no more to Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of his death is enroll'd in the Capitol, his glory not extenuated, wherein he was worthy; nor his offences enforc'd, for which he suffered death. Enter Antony and others, with Caesar's body. Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying, a place in the commonwealth; as which of you shall not? With this I depart, that, as I slew my best lover for the good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself, when it shall please my country to need my death.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Live, Brutus! live, live!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Let him be Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Caesar's better parts Shall be crown'd in Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: We'll bring him to his house with shouts and clamours.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: My countrymen,-

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Peace! Silence! Brutus speaks.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Peace, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good countrymen, let me depart alone, And, for my sake, stay here with Antony. Do grace to Caesar's corpse, and grace his speech Tending to Caesar's glories, which Mark Antony, By our permission, is allow'd to make. I do entreat you, not a man depart, Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Stay, ho! and let us hear Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Let him go up into the public chair. We'll hear him. Noble Antony, go up.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: What does he say of Brutus?

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: He says, for Brutus' sake He finds himself beholding to us all.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: This Caesar was a tyrant.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Nay, that's certain. We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Peace! let us hear what Antony can say.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You gentle Romans,-

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Peace, ho! let us hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears; I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him. The evil that men do lives after them, The good is oft interred with their bones; So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus Hath told you Caesar was ambitious. If it were so, it was a grievous fault, And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it. Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest, For Brutus is an honourable man, So are they all, all honourable men, Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral. He was my friend, faithful and just to me; But Brutus says he was ambitious, And Brutus is an honourable man. He hath brought many captives home to Rome, Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious? When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept; Ambition should be made of sterner stuff: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious; And Brutus is an honourable man. You all did see that on the Lupercal I thrice presented him a kingly crown, Which he did thrice refuse. Was this ambition? Yet Brutus says he was ambitious; And sure he is an honourable man. I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke, But here I am to speak what I do know. You all did love him once, not without cause; What cause withholds you then to mourn for him? O judgement, thou art fled to brutish beasts, And men have lost their reason. Bear with me. My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar, And I must pause till it come back to me.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: If thou consider rightly of the matter, Caesar has had great wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
