dialogues.line: Has he, masters? I fear there will a worse come in his place.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown; Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Poor soul, his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Now mark him; he begins again to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: But yesterday the word of Caesar might Have stood against the world; now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence. O masters! If I were dispos'd to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I should do Brutus wrong and Cassius wrong, Who, you all know, are honourable men. I will not do them wrong; I rather choose To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you, Than I will wrong such honourable men. But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar, I found it in his closet; 'tis his will: Let but the commons hear this testament, Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read, And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds, And dip their napkins in his sacred blood; Yea, beg a hair of him for memory, And, dying, mention it within their wills, Bequeathing it as a rich legacy Unto their issue.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: We'll hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: The will, the will! We will hear Caesar's will.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Have patience, gentle friends, I must not read it. It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you. You are not wood, you are not stones, but men; And being men, hearing the will of Caesar, It will inflame you, it will make you mad. 'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs; For if you should, O, what would come of it?

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Read the will! We'll hear it, Antony; You shall read us the will, Caesar's will!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Will you be patient? Will you stay awhile? I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it. I fear I wrong the honourable men Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: They were traitors. Honourable men!

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: The will! The testament!

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: They were villains, murderers. The will! Read the will!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You will compel me then to read the will? Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar, And let me show you him that made the will. Shall I descend? and will you give me leave?

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Come down.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Descend.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: You shall have leave.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: A ring! Stand round.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Room for Antony, most noble Antony!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Nay, press not so upon me; stand far off.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Stand back; room! bear back.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now. You all do know this mantle. I remember The first time ever Caesar put it on; 'Twas on a Summer's evening, in his tent, That day he overcame the Nervii. Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through: See what a rent the envious Casca made: Through this the well-beloved Brutus stabb'd; And as he pluck'd his cursed steel away, Mark how the blood of Caesar follow'd it, As rushing out of doors, to be resolv'd If Brutus so unkindly knock'd, or no; For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel. Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar lov'd him. This was the most unkindest cut of all; For when the noble Caesar saw him stab, Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms, Quite vanquish'd him: then burst his mighty heart; And in his mantle muffling up his face, Even at the base of Pompey's statue Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell. O, what a fall was there, my countrymen! Then I, and you, and all of us fell down, Whilst bloody treason flourish'd over us. O, now you weep; and I perceive you feel The dint of pity. These are gracious drops. Kind souls, what weep you when you but behold Our Caesar's vesture wounded? Look you here, Here is himself, marr'd, as you see, with traitors.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: O piteous spectacle!

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: O noble Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: O woeful day!

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: O traitors, villains!

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: O most bloody sight!

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: We will be revenged.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Revenge,-about,-seek,-burn,-fire,-kill,-slay,-let not a traitor live!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Stay, countrymen.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Peace there! Hear the noble Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up To such a sudden flood of mutiny. They that have done this deed are honourable. What private griefs they have, alas, I know not, That made them do it. They're wise and honourable, And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you. I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts. I am no orator, as Brutus is; But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man, That love my friend; and that they know full well That gave me public leave to speak of him. For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth, Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech, To stir men's blood. I only speak right on. I tell you that which you yourselves do know, Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor poor dumb mouths, And bid them speak for me. But were I Brutus, And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits, and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar, that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: We'll mutiny.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: We'll burn the house of Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Away, then! come, seek the conspirators.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Peace, ho! Hear Antony; most noble Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what. Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves? Alas, you know not; I must tell you then. You have forgot the will I told you of.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Most true; the will!-let's stay, and hear the will.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal. To every Roman citizen he gives, To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: O, royal Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Hear me with patience.

dialogues.speaker: Citizens
dialogues.line: Peace, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks, His private arbors, and new-planted orchards, On this side Tiber; he hath left them you, And to your heirs forever; common pleasures, To walk abroad, and recreate yourselves. Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Never, never. Come, away, away! We'll burn his body in the holy place, And with the brands fire the traitors' houses. Take up the body.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Go, fetch fire.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Pluck down benches.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Pluck down forms, windows, anything.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot, Take thou what course thou wilt! How now, fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: And thither will I straight to visit him. He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry, And in this mood will give us anything.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I heard him say Brutus and Cassius Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Belike they had some notice of the people, How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, And things unluckily charge my fantasy. I have no will to wander forth of doors, Yet something leads me forth.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Whither are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Where do you dwell?

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: Answer every man directly.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Ay, and briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Ay, and wisely.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Ay, and truly, you were best.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly. Wisely I say I am a bachelor.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: That's as much as to say they are fools that marry; you'll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed, directly.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: As a friend, or an enemy?

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: As a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Second Citizen
dialogues.line: That matter is answered directly.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: For your dwelling, briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Your name, sir, truly.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: Truly, my name is Cinna.

dialogues.speaker: First Citizen
dialogues.line: Tear him to pieces! He's a conspirator.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad verses.

dialogues.speaker: Cinna
dialogues.line: I am not Cinna the conspirator.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Citizen
dialogues.line: It is no matter, his name's Cinna; pluck but his name out of his heart, and turn him going.

dialogues.speaker: Third Citizen
dialogues.line: Tear him, tear him! Come; brands, ho! firebrands. To Brutus', to Cassius'; burn all. Some to Decius' house, and some to Casca's, some to Ligarius'. Away, go!

scenes.location: Rome. A room in Antony's house.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: These many then shall die; their names are prick'd.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Your brother too must die; consent you, Lepidus?

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: I do consent,-

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Prick him down, Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Upon condition Publius shall not live, Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him. But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house; Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: What, shall I find you here?

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Or here, or at the Capitol.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: This is a slight unmeritable man, Meet to be sent on errands. Is it fit, The three-fold world divided, he should stand One of the three to share it?

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: So you thought him, And took his voice who should be prick'd to die In our black sentence and proscription.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Octavius, I have seen more days than you; And though we lay these honours on this man, To ease ourselves of divers sland'rous loads, He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold, To groan and sweat under the business, Either led or driven, as we point the way; And having brought our treasure where we will, Then take we down his load, and turn him off, Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears, And graze in commons.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: You may do your will; But he's a tried and valiant soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: So is my horse, Octavius; and for that I do appoint him store of provender. It is a creature that I teach to fight, To wind, to stop, to run directly on, His corporal motion govern'd by my spirit. And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so: He must be taught, and train'd, and bid go forth: A barren-spirited fellow; one that feeds On objects, arts, and imitations, Which, out of use and stal'd by other men, Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him But as a property. And now, Octavius, Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius Are levying powers; we must straight make head. Therefore let our alliance be combin'd, Our best friends made, our means stretch'd; And let us presently go sit in council, How covert matters may be best disclos'd, And open perils surest answered.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Let us do so: for we are at the stake, And bay'd about with many enemies; And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear, Millions of mischiefs.

scenes.location: Before Brutus' tent, in the camp near Sardis.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Stand, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: Give the word, ho! and stand.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What now, Lucilius! is Cassius near?

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He greets me well. Your master, Pindarus, In his own change, or by ill officers, Hath given me some worthy cause to wish Things done, undone: but, if he be at hand, I shall be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Pindarus
dialogues.line: I do not doubt But that my noble master will appear Such as he is, full of regard and honour.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He is not doubted. A word, Lucilius; How he received you, let me be resolv'd.

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: With courtesy and with respect enough, But not with such familiar instances, Nor with such free and friendly conference, As he hath us'd of old.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Thou hast describ'd A hot friend cooling. Ever note, Lucilius, When love begins to sicken and decay It useth an enforced ceremony. There are no tricks in plain and simple faith; But hollow men, like horses hot at hand, Make gallant show and promise of their mettle; But when they should endure the bloody spur, They fall their crests, and like deceitful jades Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: They meant this night in Sardis to be quarter'd; The greater part, the horse in general, Are come with Cassius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Hark! he is arriv'd. March gently on to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Stand, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Stand, ho! Speak the word along.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Stand!

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Stand!

dialogues.speaker: Third Soldier
dialogues.line: Stand!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Judge me, you gods; wrong I mine enemies? And if not so, how should I wrong a brother?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs; And when you do them-

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Cassius, be content. Speak your griefs softly, I do know you well. Before the eyes of both our armies here, Which should perceive nothing but love from us, Let us not wrangle. Bid them move away; Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs, And I will give you audience.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Pindarus, Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Lucilius, do you the like; and let no man Come to our tent till we have done our conference. Lucius and Titinius, guard our door.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this: You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians; Wherein my letters, praying on his side Because I knew the man, were slighted off.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You wrong'd yourself to write in such a case.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offence should bear his comment.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm, To sell and mart your offices for gold To undeservers.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I an itching palm! You know that you are Brutus that speak this, Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The name of Cassius honours this corruption, And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Chastisement!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Remember March, the Ides of March remember: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake? What villain touch'd his body, that did stab, And not for justice? What! Shall one of us, That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers, shall we now Contaminate our fingers with base bribes, And sell the mighty space of our large honours For so much trash as may be grasped thus? I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon, Than such a Roman.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Brutus, bait not me, I'll not endure it. You forget yourself, To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I, Older in practice, abler than yourself To make conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Go to; you are not, Cassius.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I say you are not.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself; Have mind upon your health, tempt me no farther.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Away, slight man!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Is't possible?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Hear me, for I will speak. Must I give way and room to your rash choler? Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: O ye gods, ye gods! Must I endure all this?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: All this? ay, more: fret till your proud heart break; Go show your slaves how choleric you are, And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge? Must I observe you? Must I stand and crouch Under your testy humour? By the gods, You shall digest the venom of your spleen, Though it do split you; for, from this day forth, I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter, When you are waspish.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Is it come to this?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You say you are a better soldier: Let it appear so; make your vaunting true, And it shall please me well. For mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: You wrong me every way, you wrong me, Brutus. I said, an elder soldier, not a better: Did I say better?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: If you did, I care not.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: When Caesar liv'd, he durst not thus have mov'd me.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Peace, peace! you durst not so have tempted him.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I durst not?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: What? durst not tempt him?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: For your life you durst not.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Do not presume too much upon my love. I may do that I shall be sorry for.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You have done that you should be sorry for. There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, For I am arm'd so strong in honesty, That they pass by me as the idle wind, Which I respect not. I did send to you For certain sums of gold, which you denied me; For I can raise no money by vile means: By Heaven, I had rather coin my heart, And drop my blood for drachmas, than to wring From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash By any indirection. I did send To you for gold to pay my legions, Which you denied me: was that done like Cassius? Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so? When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous, To lock such rascal counters from his friends, Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts, Dash him to pieces!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I denied you not.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: You did.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I did not. He was but a fool That brought my answer back. Brutus hath riv'd my heart. A friend should bear his friend's infirmities; But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I do not, till you practise them on me.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: You love me not.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I do not like your faults.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: A flatterer's would not, though they do appear As huge as high Olympus.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come, Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius, For Cassius is a-weary of the world: Hated by one he loves; brav'd by his brother; Check'd like a bondman; all his faults observ'd, Set in a note-book, learn'd and conn'd by rote, To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger, And here my naked breast; within, a heart Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold: If that thou be'st a Roman, take it forth. I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart: Strike as thou didst at Caesar; for I know, When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Sheathe your dagger. Be angry when you will, it shall have scope; Do what you will, dishonour shall be humour. O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb That carries anger as the flint bears fire, Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark, And straight is cold again.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Hath Cassius liv'd To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus, When grief and blood ill-temper'd vexeth him?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: When I spoke that, I was ill-temper'd too.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: And my heart too.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: O Brutus!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Have not you love enough to bear with me, When that rash humour which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Yes, Cassius; and from henceforth, When you are over-earnest with your Brutus, He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Let me go in to see the generals, There is some grudge between 'em; 'tis not meet They be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: You shall not come to them.

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: Nothing but death shall stay me.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: How now! What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Poet
dialogues.line: For shame, you generals! What do you mean? Love, and be friends, as two such men should be; For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Ha, ha! How vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Get you hence, sirrah. Saucy fellow, hence!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Bear with him, Brutus; 'tis his fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I'll know his humour when he knows his time. What should the wars do with these jigging fools? Companion, hence!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Away, away, be gone!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: And come yourselves and bring Messala with you Immediately to us.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Lucius, a bowl of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I did not think you could have been so angry.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Of your philosophy you make no use, If you give place to accidental evils.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Ha? Portia?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: She is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: How 'scap'd I killing, when I cross'd you so? O insupportable and touching loss! Upon what sickness?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong; for with her death That tidings came. With this she fell distract, And, her attendants absent, swallow'd fire.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: And died so?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Even so.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: O ye immortal gods!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine. In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge. Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup. I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come in, Titinius! Welcome, good Messala. Now sit we close about this taper here, And call in question our necessities.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Portia, art thou gone?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No more, I pray you. Messala, I have here received letters, That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: With what addition?

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: That by proscription and bills of outlawry Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred Senators.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Therein our letters do not well agree. Mine speak of seventy Senators that died By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Cicero one!

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Cicero is dead, And by that order of proscription. Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No, Messala.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Nothing, Messala.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: That, methinks, is strange.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why ask you? Hear you aught of her in yours?

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: No, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Now as you are a Roman, tell me true.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell, For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala. With meditating that she must die once, I have the patience to endure it now.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Even so great men great losses should endure.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Well, to our work alive. What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I do not think it good.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Your reason?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: This it is: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us; So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offence, whilst we, lying still, Are full of rest, defence, and nimbleness.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good reasons must of force give place to better. The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground Do stand but in a forced affection; For they have grudg'd us contribution. The enemy, marching along by them, By them shall make a fuller number up, Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encourag'd; From which advantage shall we cut him off If at Philippi we do face him there, These people at our back.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Hear me, good brother.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Under your pardon. You must note besides, That we have tried the utmost of our friends, Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe. The enemy increaseth every day; We, at the height, are ready to decline. There is a tide in the affairs of men, Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; Omitted, all the voyage of their life Is bound in shallows and in miseries. On such a full sea are we now afloat, And we must take the current when it serves, Or lose our ventures.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Then, with your will, go on: We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: The deep of night is crept upon our talk, And nature must obey necessity, Which we will niggard with a little rest. There is no more to say?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: No more. Good night: Early tomorrow will we rise, and hence.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Lucius! My gown. Farewell now, good Messala. Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius, Good night, and good repose.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: O my dear brother! This was an ill beginning of the night. Never come such division 'tween our souls! Let it not, Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Everything is well.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Good night, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good night, good brother. TITINIUS and MESSALA. Good night, Lord Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Farewell, everyone. Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Here in the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: What, thou speak'st drowsily? Poor knave, I blame thee not, thou art o'er-watch'd. Call Claudius and some other of my men; I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Varro and Claudius!

dialogues.speaker: Varro
dialogues.line: Calls my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep; It may be I shall raise you by-and-by On business to my brother Cassius.

dialogues.speaker: Varro
dialogues.line: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I will not have it so; lie down, good sirs, It may be I shall otherwise bethink me. Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so; I put it in the pocket of my gown.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful. Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile, And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Ay, my lord, an't please you.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: It does, my boy. I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: It is my duty, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: I should not urge thy duty past thy might; I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: I have slept, my lord, already.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again; I will not hold thee long. If I do live, I will be good to thee. This is a sleepy tune. O murd'rous slumber, Layest thou thy leaden mace upon my boy, That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night; I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee. If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument; I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night. Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down Where I left reading? Here it is, I think. How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here? I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition. It comes upon me. Art thou anything? Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil, That mak'st my blood cold and my hair to stare? Speak to me what thou art.

dialogues.speaker: Ghost
dialogues.line: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why com'st thou?

dialogues.speaker: Ghost
dialogues.line: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Well; then I shall see thee again?

dialogues.speaker: Ghost
dialogues.line: Ay, at Philippi.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why, I will see thee at Philippi then. Now I have taken heart, thou vanishest. Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee. Boy! Lucius! Varro! Claudius! Sirs, awake! Claudius!

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: The strings, my lord, are false.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: He thinks he still is at his instrument. Lucius, awake!

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Yes, that thou didst. Didst thou see anything?

dialogues.speaker: Lucius
dialogues.line: Nothing, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Sleep again, Lucius. Sirrah Claudius! Fellow thou, awake!

dialogues.speaker: Varro
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Claudius
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep? VARRO. CLAUDIUS. Did we, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Ay. Saw you anything?

dialogues.speaker: Varro
dialogues.line: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Claudius
dialogues.line: Nor I, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius; Bid him set on his powers betimes before, And we will follow. VARRO. CLAUDIUS. It shall be done, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Now, Antony, our hopes are answered. You said the enemy would not come down, But keep the hills and upper regions. It proves not so; their battles are at hand, They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know Wherefore they do it. They could be content To visit other places, and come down With fearful bravery, thinking by this face To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage; But 'tis not so.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Prepare you, generals. The enemy comes on in gallant show; Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Octavius, lead your battle softly on Upon the left hand of the even field.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Upon the right hand I. Keep thou the left.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: I do not cross you; but I will do so. Drum. Enter Brutus, Cassius and their Army; Lucilius, Titinius, Messala and others.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: They stand, and would have parley.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Stand fast, Titinius; we must out and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge. Make forth; the generals would have some words.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Stir not until the signal.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Not that we love words better, as you do.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words; Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart, Crying, "Long live! Hail, Caesar!"

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Antony, The posture of your blows are yet unknown; But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees, And leave them honeyless.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Not stingless too.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O yes, and soundless too, For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony, And very wisely threat before you sting.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar: You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds, And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet; Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Flatterers! Now, Brutus, thank yourself. This tongue had not offended so today, If Cassius might have rul'd.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Come, come, the cause. If arguing makes us sweat, The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look, I draw a sword against conspirators. When think you that the sword goes up again? Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds Be well aveng'd; or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands, Unless thou bring'st them with thee.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: So I hope. I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: A peevish school-boy, worthless of such honour, Join'd with a masker and a reveller.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Old Cassius still!

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Come, Antony; away! Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth. If you dare fight today, come to the field; If not, when you have stomachs.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Why now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark! The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Ho, Lucilius! Hark, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Messala.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: What says my General?

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Messala, This is my birth-day; as this very day Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala: Be thou my witness that against my will As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set Upon one battle all our liberties. You know that I held Epicurus strong, And his opinion. Now I change my mind, And partly credit things that do presage. Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd, Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands, Who to Philippi here consorted us. This morning are they fled away and gone, And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites Fly o'er our heads, and downward look on us, As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Believe not so.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: I but believe it partly, For I am fresh of spirit, and resolv'd To meet all perils very constantly.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Even so, Lucilius.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly, that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age! But, since the affairs of men rest still incertain, Let's reason with the worst that may befall. If we do lose this battle, then is this The very last time we shall speak together: What are you then determined to do?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Even by the rule of that philosophy By which I did blame Cato for the death Which he did give himself, I know not how, But I do find it cowardly and vile, For fear of what might fall, so to prevent The time of life, arming myself with patience To stay the providence of some high powers That govern us below.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Then, if we lose this battle, You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: No, Cassius, no: think not, thou noble Roman, That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome; He bears too great a mind. But this same day Must end that work the Ides of March begun; And whether we shall meet again I know not. Therefore our everlasting farewell take. For ever, and for ever, farewell, Cassius. If we do meet again, why, we shall smile; If not, why then this parting was well made.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: For ever and for ever farewell, Brutus. If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed; If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why then, lead on. O, that a man might know The end of this day's business ere it come! But it sufficeth that the day will end, And then the end is known. Come, ho! away!

scenes.location: The same. The field of battle.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side. Let them set on at once; for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing, And sudden push gives them the overthrow. Ride, ride, Messala; let them all come down.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly! Myself have to mine own turn'd enemy: This ensign here of mine was turning back; I slew the coward, and did take it from him.

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly: his soldiers fell to spoil, Whilst we by Antony are all enclos'd.

dialogues.speaker: Pindarus
dialogues.line: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off; Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord. Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius; Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: They are, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse and hide thy spurs in him, Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again, that I may rest assur'd Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: I will be here again, even with a thought.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill, My sight was ever thick. Regard Titinius, And tell me what thou notest about the field. This day I breathed first. Time is come round, And where I did begin, there shall I end. My life is run his compass. Sirrah, what news?

dialogues.speaker: Pindarus
dialogues.line: O my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: What news?

dialogues.speaker: Pindarus
dialogues.line: Titinius is enclosed round about With horsemen, that make to him on the spur, Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him. Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too. He's ta'en! And, hark! they shout for joy.

dialogues.speaker: Cassius
dialogues.line: Come down; behold no more. O, coward that I am, to live so long, To see my best friend ta'en before my face! Come hither, sirrah. In Parthia did I take thee prisoner; And then I swore thee, saving of thy life, That whatsoever I did bid thee do, Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath. Now be a freeman; and with this good sword, That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom. Stand not to answer. Here, take thou the hilts; And when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now, Guide thou the sword.-Caesar, thou art reveng'd, Even with the sword that kill'd thee.

dialogues.speaker: Pindarus
dialogues.line: So, I am free, yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will. O Cassius! Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power, As Cassius' legions are by Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: These tidings would well comfort Cassius.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Where did you leave him?

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Is not that he that lies upon the ground?

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Is not that he?

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: No, this was he, Messala, But Cassius is no more. O setting sun, As in thy red rays thou dost sink to night, So in his red blood Cassius' day is set. The sun of Rome is set. Our day is gone; Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done. Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed. O hateful Error, Melancholy's child! Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men The things that are not? O Error, soon conceiv'd, Thou never com'st unto a happy birth, But kill'st the mother that engender'd thee!

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: What, Pindarus! where art thou, Pindarus?

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears. I may say thrusting it; For piercing steel and darts envenomed Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight.

dialogues.speaker: Titinius
dialogues.line: Hie you, Messala, And I will seek for Pindarus the while. Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius? Did I not meet thy friends? And did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory, And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts? Alas, thou hast misconstrued everything! But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow; Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace, And see how I regarded Caius Cassius. By your leave, gods. This is a Roman's part. Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart. Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, young Cato, Strato, Volumnius and Lucilius.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Titinius' face is upward.

dialogues.speaker: Cato
dialogues.line: He is slain.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet! Thy spirit walks abroad, and turns our swords In our own proper entrails.

dialogues.speaker: Cato
dialogues.line: Brave Titinius! Look whether he have not crown'd dead Cassius!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Are yet two Romans living such as these? The last of all the Romans, fare thee well! It is impossible that ever Rome Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears To this dead man than you shall see me pay. I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time. Come therefore, and to Thassos send his body. His funerals shall not be in our camp, Lest it discomfort us. Lucilius, come; And come, young Cato; let us to the field. Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on. 'Tis three o'clock; and Romans, yet ere night We shall try fortune in a second fight.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!

dialogues.speaker: Cato
dialogues.line: What bastard doth not? Who will go with me? I will proclaim my name about the field. I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho! A foe to tyrants, and my country's friend. I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I; Brutus, my country's friend; know me for Brutus!

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: O young and noble Cato, art thou down? Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius, And mayst be honour'd, being Cato's son.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Yield, or thou diest.

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: Only I yield to die: There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight; Kill Brutus, and be honour'd in his death.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: We must not. A noble prisoner!

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Room, ho! Tell Antony, Brutus is ta'en.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: I'll tell the news. Here comes the General. Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: Safe, Antony; Brutus is safe enough. I dare assure thee that no enemy Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus. The gods defend him from so great a shame! When you do find him, or alive or dead, He will be found like Brutus, like himself.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: This is not Brutus, friend; but, I assure you, A prize no less in worth. Keep this man safe, Give him all kindness. I had rather have Such men my friends than enemies. Go on, And see whether Brutus be alive or dead; And bring us word unto Octavius' tent How everything is chanc'd.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: Statilius show'd the torch-light; but, my lord, He came not back: he is or ta'en or slain.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Sit thee down, Clitus. Slaying is the word; It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Peace then, no words.

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: I'll rather kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Hark thee, Dardanius.

dialogues.speaker: Dardanius
dialogues.line: Shall I do such a deed?

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: O Dardanius!

dialogues.speaker: Dardanius
dialogues.line: O Clitus!

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

dialogues.speaker: Dardanius
dialogues.line: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: Now is that noble vessel full of grief, That it runs over even at his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Come hither, good Volumnius; list a word.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnius
dialogues.line: What says my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Why, this, Volumnius: The ghost of Caesar hath appear'd to me Two several times by night; at Sardis once, And this last night here in Philippi fields. I know my hour is come.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnius
dialogues.line: Not so, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Nay I am sure it is, Volumnius. Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes; Our enemies have beat us to the pit. It is more worthy to leap in ourselves Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius, Thou know'st that we two went to school together; Even for that our love of old, I pr'ythee Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.

dialogues.speaker: Volumnius
dialogues.line: That's not an office for a friend, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: Fly, fly, my lord! there is no tarrying here.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Farewell to you; and you; and you, Volumnius. Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep; Farewell to thee too, Strato.-Countrymen, My heart doth joy, that yet in all my life I found no man but he was true to me. I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto. So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue Hath almost ended his life's history. Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest, That have but labour'd to attain this hour.

dialogues.speaker: Clitus
dialogues.line: Fly, my lord, fly!

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Hence! I will follow. I pr'ythee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord. Thou art a fellow of a good respect; Thy life hath had some smatch of honour in it. Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face, While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?

dialogues.speaker: Strato
dialogues.line: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Brutus
dialogues.line: Farewell, good Strato.-Caesar, now be still: I kill'd not thee with half so good a will. Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octavius, Messala, Lucilius and the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: What man is that?

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: My master's man. Strato, where is thy master?

dialogues.speaker: Strato
dialogues.line: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala. The conquerors can but make a fire of him; For Brutus only overcame himself, And no man else hath honour by his death.

dialogues.speaker: Lucilius
dialogues.line: So Brutus should be found. I thank thee, Brutus, That thou hast prov'd Lucilius' saying true.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: All that serv'd Brutus, I will entertain them. Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

dialogues.speaker: Strato
dialogues.line: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: Do so, good Messala.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: How died my master, Strato?

dialogues.speaker: Strato
dialogues.line: I held the sword, and he did run on it.

dialogues.speaker: Messala
dialogues.line: Octavius, then take him to follow thee, That did the latest service to my master.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: This was the noblest Roman of them all. All the conspirators save only he, Did that they did in envy of great Caesar; He only, in a general honest thought And common good to all, made one of them. His life was gentle, and the elements So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up And say to all the world, "This was a man!"

dialogues.speaker: Octavius
dialogues.line: According to his virtue let us use him With all respect and rites of burial. Most like a soldier, order'd honourably. So call the field to rest, and let's away, To part the glories of this happy day.
